Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Student Travel Grant for the ACM MobiCom 2015 Conference

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
ACM MobiCom conference is the leading international conference on mobile computing and wireless networking. It invites research contributions addressing the challenges in the area of mobile computing, from the perspective of networks, wireless and mobile systems, algorithms, and applications. The conference features a high-quality technical program, with an acceptance rate of around 10% out of around 250 submissions. It has a single-track session, which offers significant opportunities for individual and small groups that foster technical and social interactions among a diverse set of participants. MobiCom is also an international conference that stimulates exchanges between various international research communities.

This award will help increase the representation and participation of United States-based students at the conference by providing 20 travel grants. By creating new opportunities for graduate students, especially those from under-represented groups, to attend a high-quality conference, this award will benefit the students by giving them an opportunity to interact with world-class researchers, inspire them to try new research directions, providing mentoring opportunities, as well as the chance to seek out internships and post-doctoral positions which will help the students advance in their research career.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twenty students from US-based universities were awarded $1,250 travel grant to attend 2015 MobiCom conference at Paris, France, from 9/7/15 to 9/11/15. The travel grant paid for their conference registration fees and 4 days of lodging and meal expenses at Paris. The students were able to present their research results to their peers in the computer science.  The participation in the conference has an important impact in shaping the students' future career, either in academics or private industries through their exposure to well established researchers in their research areas.

A total of thirty-three students from 24 universities applied for the travel grants. Twenty students were selected based on the selection criteria described in the proposal. Nineteen of the 24 universities were public universities, and 18 students from these universities received travel grant.

One of the objectives of the travel grant is to encourage participation of female students in the computer science. Women currently hold less than 25% of the STEM related job. Twenty-nine percent of the travel grant applicants were female students; six selected based on the selection criterias desribed in the proposal. Five of the female travel grant awardees presented their papers in the conference. Further outreach activities is still needed in order to increase higher participation in STEM by female, and other represented minorities.
